title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license, or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willfully transferring armor piercing ammunition. Additionally, the Secretary can compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any willful violation of firearm regulations. The Secretary can review actions under this chapter, with review rights provided in subsection (f) for applicants and licensees. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or imposes a civil penalty, written notice stating the grounds must be provided to the affected party. The Secretary must provide written notice of the grounds for denial, revocation, suspension, or civil penalty. An appeal process is available for the aggrieved party upon request. Upon request, the Secretary will promptly hold a hearing to review the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment. The hearing will be held at a convenient location for the aggrieved party. If the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision after the hearing, notice of the decision will be provided, and an appeal process is available. The Secretary will notify the aggrieved party of the decision. The party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days in the district court where they reside or have a principal place of business. The aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days in the district court where they reside or have a principal place of business. In the judicial proceeding, the court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was considered at the initial hearing. The court can order the Secretary to comply with its judgment if it finds that the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment was unauthorized. The Secretary must stay any license suspension, revocation, or civil penalty upon request pending appeal. The Secretary must stay any license suspension, revocation, or civil penalty upon request pending appeal. Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
